The Nature of Code Book and Videos

01 February 2013

The Nature of Code is a wonderful creative programming class taught at ITP by Dan Shiffman. In The Nature of Code, students learn how to programme software applications that mimic nature in some way, covering topics like gravity, wind, flocking, learning and evolution. For my own final project I made a little simulation where creatures are born, flock, find food, react to danger, age and die.

The class was a real revelation for me. I wasn't good at maths or physics in school, and only really started to grasp concepts like trigonometry, vectors and forces in Dan's class. I really wish that a class like this (and more creative methods of teaching) had been available when I was much younger.

Dan has just released a book that covers, and expands upon, the content of the class. There's a freely available library of code and Dan is recording a series of (highly entertaining) videos to help students along.

I can't recommend The Nature of Code highly enough. Enjoy the content from the class, and help it finds its way to people teaching maths, physics, biology, or computing to young people.
